context: This regulatory regime recognizes that water quantity and quality at a surface-water compliance point is a function of the upstream catchment's landuse, hydrology and hydrogeology. Diffuse or point-source land contamination within urban areas may cause contaminated groundwater baseflows that in turn contaminate surface waters potentially impacting a downstream compliance point and the ecological health of the watercourse. The city-scale impact of contaminated land and associated groundwater contamination upon urban surface waters is largely unknown. VOCs (volatile organic compounds), in particular the chlorinated solvents such as trichloroethene (TCE) probably represent the most troublesome class of organic contaminants found in urban groundwater to date (Pankow and Cherry, 1996). They are dense non-aqueous-phase liquids (DNAPLs) able to penetrate deep below the water table where they slowly dissolve to form plumes over decades. Plumes may attain km-scale lengths due to their low sorption, limited chemical reaction and varied, but often low, biodegradation potential (Jackson, 1998; Rivett et al., 2001). Due to their widespread use, mobility and persistence, such chlorinated VOCs are considered to have perhaps the greatest potential of all industrially contaminated land-derived contaminants to discharge to surface waters as contaminated baseflow.
